trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of stretching in patients with persisting pain - a randomised controlled trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effects of stretching in patients with persisting pain - a randomised controlled trial

interventions.interventions:
The two legs of each subject are randomised into either the treatment or control condition.
Intervention: The hamstring muscles of the treatment leg will be stretched for 1 minute per day for three weeks.
interventions.comparator: Control Condition: Meanwhile, the hamstring muscles of the control leg will receive no specific stretch intervention during the three-week period.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in passive hip flexion angle with standardised torque to measure hamstring muscle extensibility
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at the end of the 3-week stretching program (24 hours after the last stretch treatment)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in passive hip flexion angle at the highest tolerated torque to measure stretch tolerance
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at the end of the 3-week stretch program (24 hours after the last stretch treatment)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mean change in pain intensity as reported on the 10-point numerical rating scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at the end of the 3-week stretch program (24 hours after the last stretch treatment)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pain persisting for greater than three months, no further medical or surgical investigations or treatments planned, not requiring urgent psychiatric treatment, no primary drug or alcohol problem, inextensible hamstring muscles as tested using a standard "toe-touch" test.

trial_design.concealment: A concealed allocation schedule was used. Allocation involved the supervising physiotherapist contacting the holder of the allocation schedule, who was located at an "off-site" centre.
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation was achieved by using a randomisation table created by a computer software (computerised sequence generation).
trial_design.designfeatures: The assessor and data analyst are blinded to treatment allocation. The subjects and supervising therapist were unable to be blinded due to the design of the intervention.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this study is to determine whether a three-week stretching program can increase hamstring muscle extensibility or improve tolerance to stretch in patients with persisting pain. Our hypothesis is that stretching will not increase the extensibility of the hamstring muscles, but rather, will increase the subjects' tolerance to an uncomfortable stretch sensation.
